questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a 45-year-old male patient exhibits an unusual waveform on the capnography monitor, resembling the picture shown below. He is under general anesthesia. What condition could lead to this characteristic appearance on the ETCO2 monitor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "shark fin" appearance on capnography is a key indicator of bronchospasm , which is caused by restricted airflow during exhalation due to airway constriction.
  • ➤ bronchospasm

questions.text: What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? 1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute 2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute 3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm 4. Allow chest recoil
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High-quality CPR requires a chest compression rate of 100-120 per minute, a compression depth of 5-6 cm, and full chest recoil between compressions.

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16: Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume:
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, previously intubated for one week due to respiratory failure, becomes agitated and self-extubates. His respiratory rate is 20 and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

questions.correct_answer: D. Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After self-extubation, if a patient is stable with normal respiratory rate and oxygenation, the appropriate management is to monitor for spontaneous breathing and intervene only if the patient begins to show signs of respiratory distress or deterioration.
  • ➤ monitor for spontaneous breathing

questions.text: Identify the maximum FiO2 of the equipment shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 100%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) can deliver oxygen at up to 100% FiO2 , making it a valuable tool for non-invasive respiratory support in critically ill patients.
  • ➤ High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)
  • ➤ up to 100% FiO2

questions.text: Which of these is not a pattern of nerve stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Quadruple burst stimulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Quadruple burst stimulation is not a recognized pattern of nerve stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. The common patterns used are TOF , Double burst stimulation , and Post tetanic count .
  • ➤ Quadruple burst stimulation
  • ➤ TOF
  • ➤ Double burst stimulation
  • ➤ Post tetanic count

questions.text: Which of the following equipment is required for putting an intravenous cannula in a newborn? 22G needle 24G needle 5-mL syringe Adhesive tape Normal saline
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the required equipment includes a 24G needle , 5-mL syringe , adhesive tape , and normal saline for flushing the line.
  • ➤ 24G needle
  • ➤ 5-mL syringe
  • ➤ adhesive tape
  • ➤ normal saline

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation (RSI).

options.label: A
options.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.

options.label: B
options.text: High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is not used in cardiac arrest patients . In such cases, immediate intubation is performed without the use of induction agents or muscle relaxants.
  • ➤ Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is not used in cardiac arrest patients

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In line manual stabilization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In line manual stabilization is a critical maneuver used to protect the cervical spine in trauma patients during airway management and other procedures, preventing further injury by maintaining neutral alignment.
  • ➤ In line manual stabilization

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is found lying face down on the ground by a bystander who notes that she is unresponsive. The bystander is trained in basic life support and checks for responsiveness and breathing. The patient is not responding to verbal commands or physical stimuli, but she is breathing shallowly. The bystander notes a weak carotid pulse. Emergency medical services have been activated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Turn the patient onto her back and begin chest compressions.

options.label: B
options.text: Maintain the patient in the prone position and wait for emergency medical services.

options.label: C
options.text: Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.

options.label: D
options.text: Provide rescue breathing while keeping the patient in the current position.

questions.correct_answer: C. Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an unresponsive patient who is breathing and has a pulse, the best course of action is to move the patient to the recovery position to protect the airway and prevent complications such as aspiration.
  • ➤ move the patient to the recovery position

questions.text: Which of the following is the composition of a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics (EMLA)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lidocaine and prilocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EMLA cream contains a 2.5% concentration of both lidocaine and prilocaine , and it is used to provide local anesthesia for procedures such as IV line insertion.
  • ➤ EMLA cream
  • ➤ 2.5% concentration of both lidocaine and prilocaine

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia team needs to ensure the proper connection of the oxygen supply. Which of the following PIN (Pin-Index) configurations corresponds to the oxygen supply in medical gas cylinders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2,5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pin-index configuration for oxygen in medical gas cylinders is 2,5 , and oxygen cylinders are typically identified by a black body with a white shoulder .
  • ➤ pin-index configuration for oxygen
  • ➤ 2,5
  • ➤ black body with a white shoulder

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of severe anxiety is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure. The anesthesia team decides to use a dissociative anesthetic for induction. Which of the following drugs is a commonly used dissociative anesthetic and is suitable for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is the most commonly used dissociative anesthetic , especially in patients with anxiety, as it induces a trance-like state with preserved airway reflexes and stable cardiovascular function.
  • ➤ Ketamine
  • ➤ dissociative anesthetic

questions.text: Identify the laryngeal mask airway from the picture below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ProSeal LMA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ProSeal LMA is a widely used second-generation LMA with a dual-lumen design, including a drain tube for gastric content management and an inflatable cuff for airway sealing.
  • ➤ ProSeal LMA

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was posted for appendectomy. On further examination, the child was not allowing touch by the anesthesiologist. It was decided to take the child for inhalational induction of anesthesia. Which of the following will be the inhalational agent of choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for pediatric anesthesia induction due to its rapid onset, non-irritating properties, and favorable safety profile, especially in children who are anxious or uncooperative.
  • ➤ Sevoflurane

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing elective orthopedic surgery requires neuromuscular blockade. Given his history of malignant hyperthermia, the anesthesiologist opts to use a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Which additional agent should be avoided in this patient due to potential exacerbation of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Isoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Volatile inhalational anesthetics , such as Isoflurane , must be avoided in patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia, as they can trigger the condition, while intravenous agents are generally safe.
  • ➤ Volatile inhalational anesthetics
  • ➤ Isoflurane

questions.text: During a complex abdominal surgery, the anesthesiologist decides to use a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent for muscle relaxation. Which of the following patient factors would necessitate an adjustment in the dosing regimen of this medication?
questions.correct_answer: A. Concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics can potentiate the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, necessitating an adjustment in their dosing regimen to prevent prolonged paralysis.
  • ➤ concurrent use of aminoglycoside antibiotics
  • ➤ potentiate

questions.text: A 70-year-old female is scheduled for a total hip replacement. To monitor neuromuscular blockade, the anesthesiologist decides to use a nerve stimulator. Considering the patient's history of peripheral neuropathy, which nerve is preferred for neuro-monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulnar nerve is the preferred choice for neuromuscular monitoring in patients, particularly those with peripheral neuropathy, due to its accessibility, reliability, and reduced likelihood of being affected by neuropathy.
  • ➤ ulnar nerve

questions.text: A patient with a known genetic susceptibility to pseudocholinesterase deficiency requires an emergency C-section under general anesthesia. Which of the following muscle relaxants should be avoided to prevent prolonged neuromuscular blockade?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Succinylcholine (Scoline) must be avoided in patients with pseudocholinesterase deficiency , as it can result in prolonged neuromuscular blockade. Non-depolarizing agents such as tubocurarine are safer options.
  • ➤ Succinylcholine (Scoline)
  • ➤ pseudocholinesterase deficiency
  • ➤ tubocurarine

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Mallampati Class II , the soft palate, base of the uvula, and hard palate are visible, but the tonsillar pillars and the tip of the uvula are not.
  • ➤ Mallampati Class II

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. Anesthesia is induced without any complications, and the patient is intubated using a cuffed endotracheal tube. During the surgical procedure, you notice a change in the capnography waveform. Instead of a normal square waveform, there is a gradual upslope during the expiratory phase and a decreased end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) value. Based on the capnography findings, what is the most likely explanation for the observed changes?

options.label: C
options.text: Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Equipment malfunction in the CO2 monitoring system

questions.correct_answer: C. Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with COPD or a history of smoking, changes in the capnography waveform such as a gradual upslope during expiration and decreased ETCO2 typically indicate airway obstruction or increased airway resistance due to bronchospasm or narrowed airways.
  • ➤ COPD
  • ➤ gradual upslope
  • ➤ airway obstruction or increased airway resistance

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a known hypertensive is posted for laparoscopic appendectomy under general anesthesia. Post-surgery, his serum creatinine rises to 4.5, and he develops kidney failure. What could be the causative inhalational agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methoxyflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methoxyflurane is a potent inhalational anesthetic known for its nephrotoxic effects, which can lead to kidney failure, particularly in patients who develop high serum creatinine levels post-surgery.
  • ➤ Methoxyflurane
  • ➤ nephrotoxic

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe asthma is scheduled for an appendectomy. Which of the following induction agents will cause the least respiratory depression and is preferred in asthma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is the induction agent of choice for patients with asthma because it has bronchodilatory effects and causes minimal respiratory depression , making it the safest option in this scenario.
  • ➤ Ketamine
  • ➤ asthma
  • ➤ bronchodilatory effects
  • ➤ respiratory depression

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is scheduled for an emergency exploratory laparotomy due to a suspected intestinal obstruction. Considering his cardiac history, the anesthesiologist must choose an induction agent that will cause the least myocardial depression while maintaining hemodynamic stability. Which intravenous anesthetic should be selected for the induction of anesthesia in this patient to minimize the risk of myocardial depression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Etomidate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate is the best choice for induction in patients with chronic heart failure due to its minimal effects on myocardial depression and its ability to maintain hemodynamic stability .
  • ➤ Etomidate
  • ➤ chronic heart failure
  • ➤ hemodynamic stability

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath. On physical examination, he appears to be in respiratory distress. The resident decides to assess his oxygenation status immediately using a non-invasive device. Which of the following is most accurately measured by the device applied to the patient's finger?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pulse oximeter is a non-invasive device that accurately measures oxygen saturation (SpO2) , providing quick and essential information about the oxygenation of hemoglobin in the patient's blood.
  • ➤ pulse oximeter
  • ➤ oxygen saturation (SpO2)

questions.text: During an anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ischemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can cause vasospasm leading to ischemia , characterized by pain, pallor, and potential tissue damage in the affected limb. Immediate treatment with vasodilating agents like papaverine or lignocaine is required.
  • ➤ intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone
  • ➤ vasospasm
  • ➤ ischemia
  • ➤ papaverine
  • ➤ lignocaine

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Thiopentone?

options.label: A
options.text: Induction dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% thiopentone.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective

options.label: C
options.text: It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is ultra-short acting due to rapid metabolism & excretion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiopentone’s ultra-short duration of action is due to redistribution rather than rapid metabolism or excretion, which makes statement C the incorrect one.
  • ➤ ultra-short duration of action
  • ➤ redistribution
  • ➤ C

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a minor ambulatory surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist plans to use an induction agent that allows for rapid emergence post-procedure. Which of the following agents is the preferred induction agent used in day care surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Propofol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propofol is the preferred induction agent for day care surgery due to its rapid recovery , clear-headed emergence , and minimal side effects, making it ideal for outpatient procedures.
  • ➤ Propofol
  • ➤ day care surgery
  • ➤ rapid recovery
  • ➤ clear-headed emergence

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inspiration with cardiac oscillations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The small oscillations seen on the expiratory phase of the capnograph are indicative of cardiac oscillations , a normal phenomenon in mechanically ventilated patients due to the movement of the heart.
  • ➤ small oscillations
  • ➤ cardiac oscillations

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For unstable supraventricular tachycardia with signs of hemodynamic compromise, DC cardioversion is the immediate and preferred treatment to restore normal rhythm and stabilize the patient.
  • ➤ unstable supraventricular tachycardia
  • ➤ DC cardioversion

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of respiratory failure has been on mechanical ventilation for one week in the ICU. Suddenly, the patient becomes agitated and self-extubates. What is the recommended next step in managing this situation?

options.label: D
options.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if neede

questions.correct_answer: D. Watch for spontaneous breaths and re intubate if neede
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After self-extubation , the first step is to monitor the patient's spontaneous breathing and oxygenation. If they remain stable, re-intubation may not be necessary. However, if they show signs of respiratory distress, re-intubation should be performed.
  • ➤ self-extubation
  • ➤ monitor the patient's spontaneous breathing

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his EtCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Venous air embolism is a serious complication that can occur during surgeries involving large veins, such as the internal jugular vein. It leads to a sudden drop in EtCO2 , hypotension , and cardiac arrhythmia , and must be promptly recognized and treated.
  • ➤ Venous air embolism
  • ➤ sudden drop in EtCO2
  • ➤ hypotension
  • ➤ cardiac arrhythmia

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Automated External Defibrillator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a life-saving device used in cases of sudden cardiac arrest to deliver an electric shock to the heart, helping to restore a normal heart rhythm.
  • ➤ Automated External Defibrillator (AED)

questions.text: A patient of blunt chest trauma has been intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not correct about the initial setting?

options.label: D
options.text: Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight

questions.correct_answer: D. Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tidal volume - 12 ml/kg of actual body weight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In lung protective ventilation , the tidal volume should be set to 6-8 ml/kg of ideal body weight . A tidal volume of 12 ml/kg is too high and can lead to ventilator-induced lung injury.
  • ➤ lung protective ventilation
  • ➤ tidal volume
  • ➤ 6-8 ml/kg of ideal body weight
  • ➤ 12 ml/kg

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gold standard for confirming the position of the endotracheal tube is through end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) , as it provides immediate confirmation that the tube is in the trachea by detecting exhaled CO2.
  • ➤ gold standard
  • ➤ end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2)

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a lumbar puncture , the last structure pierced before entering the subarachnoid space to collect CSF is the arachnoid mater .
  • ➤ lumbar puncture
  • ➤ subarachnoid space
  • ➤ arachnoid mater

questions.text: A young male patient was given a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive, and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CPR with 20% intralipid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity , CPR with 20% intralipid is the best course of management, as lipid emulsion therapy can help reverse the effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST).
  • ➤ bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity
  • ➤ CPR with 20% intralipid

questions.text: What is the maximum FiO2 delivered by the device shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 80%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) can deliver a maximum FiO2 of around 80% with an oxygen flow rate of 10-15 liters per minute .
  • ➤ non-rebreathing mask
  • ➤ 80%
  • ➤ 10-15 liters per minute

questions.text: Which one is not part of the original criteria for the post-anesthesia Aldrete-Morgan Recovery Score?

options.label: A
options.text: Able to breathe deeply and cough freely

questions.correct_answer: D. Post-operative pain, nausea and vomiting
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post-operative pain, nausea and vomiting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The original Aldrete-Morgan Recovery Score evaluates basic physiological functions like movement, breathing, consciousness, and circulation. Post-operative pain, nausea, and vomiting are not part of the original score but are important considerations in overall post-operative care.
  • ➤ Aldrete-Morgan Recovery Score
  • ➤ Post-operative pain, nausea, and vomiting

questions.text: A 20-kg, 6-year-old girl develops pulseless ventricular tachycardia. As per the 2005 American Heart Association Guidelines for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation, what should be the energy level for the initial shock?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 Joules (J)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child with pulseless ventricular tachycardia weighing 20 kg , the initial defibrillation shock should be delivered at 40 Joules (2 J/kg) as per the 2005 AHA guidelines .
  • ➤ pulseless ventricular tachycardia
  • ➤ 20 kg
  • ➤ 40 Joules (2 J/kg)
  • ➤ 2005 AHA guidelines

questions.text: What is the FiO2 delivered by the device shown in the image at an oxygen flow rate of 2 L/min?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 28%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A nasal cannula delivering oxygen at a flow rate of 2 L/min provides approximately 28% FiO2 .
  • ➤ nasal cannula
  • ➤ 2 L/min
  • ➤ 28% FiO2

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic Life Support (BLS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

options.label: B
options.text: Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate

options.label: C
options.text: Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway

options.label: D
options.text: Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.correct_answer: A. Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Basic Life Support (BLS) , the correct sequence is to assess the patient's response , activate the emergency response system , check for a pulse and breathing , and then start CPR if necessary. Defibrillation should be performed after attaching an AED and following its prompts
  • ➤ Basic Life Support (BLS)
  • ➤ assess the patient's response
  • ➤ activate the emergency response system
  • ➤ check for a pulse and breathing
  • ➤ start CPR
  • ➤ Defibrillation

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty unconscious and with unrecordable BP. CPR is started. The ECG shows asystole. What is the shock energy to be delivered via the defibrillator?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients in asystole , defibrillation is not indicated . The primary management involves high-quality CPR and the administration of medications like epinephrine.
  • ➤ asystole
  • ➤ not indicated
  • ➤ high-quality CPR

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Pediatric Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (PALS) guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Cuffed endotracheal tube is not preferred due to chance of tracheal stenosis

options.label: B
options.text: Depth of chest compressions is equal to A-P diameter

options.label: C
options.text: First shock energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg

options.label: D
options.text: In infants after intubation respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths /min

questions.correct_answer: D. In infants after intubation respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths /min
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In infants after intubation, respiratory rate should be 20-30 breaths/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct respiratory rate after intubation in infants is 20-30 breaths per minute according to Pediatric ACLS (PALS) guidelines . Additionally, cuffed endotracheal tubes are now acceptable, compressions should be one-third the A-P diameter of the chest, and the initial shock energy for defibrillation is 2 J/kg.
  • ➤ correct respiratory rate
  • ➤ 20-30 breaths per minute
  • ➤ Pediatric ACLS (PALS) guidelines

questions.text: A 24-year-old young truck driver has developed a fissure in ano. What would be the ideal anesthesia for this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Saddle anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Saddle anesthesia is the ideal form of anesthesia for procedures involving the perineal and anorectal region, such as a fissure in ano , because it provides targeted anesthesia with minimal spread, allowing for a quicker recovery.
  • ➤ Saddle anesthesia
  • ➤ fissure in ano

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is undergoing surgical repair of an umbilical hernia under general anesthesia. Identify the procedure performed in the picture below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caudal anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caudal anesthesia is commonly used in pediatric patients for lower abdominal surgeries and provides effective pain control. The image depicts this technique being administered through the sacral hiatus .
  • ➤ Caudal anesthesia
  • ➤ sacral hiatus

questions.text: Mendelson’s syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aspiration during general anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mendelson’s syndrome is aspiration pneumonitis that occurs during general anesthesia , particularly in obstetric patients, due to the combination of relaxed LES, delayed gastric emptying, and increased intra-abdominal pressure.
  • ➤ Mendelson’s syndrome
  • ➤ aspiration pneumonitis
  • ➤ general anesthesia

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida is taken for emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) due to fetal distress. She had a cup of tea 8 hours ago. Which of these need not be followed for induction of general anesthesia in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Keep adequate blood and blood products ready

questions.correct_answer: D. Keep adequate blood and blood products ready
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Keep adequate blood and blood products ready

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During emergency LSCS under general anesthesia, it is crucial to have a difficult airway cart , avoid opioids before delivery , and perform rapid sequence induction to minimize aspiration risk. Keeping blood products ready is important in obstetrics but is not a requirement for induction of general anesthesia in this specific case.
  • ➤ difficult airway cart
  • ➤ opioids before delivery
  • ➤ rapid sequence induction
  • ➤ blood products ready
  • ➤ not a requirement for induction

questions.text: Assertion: General anesthesia is the preferred technique of anesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries. Reason: General anesthesia is more comfortable for parturients who have a fear of needles or surgery.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement.

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct, but Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While general anesthesia is preferred in emergency obstetric surgeries for rapid control and induction, it is not primarily chosen because of patient comfort or fear of needles. Therefore, both statements are independently correct, but they do not explain each other.
  • ➤ general anesthesia
  • ➤ emergency obstetric surgeries

questions.text: A child with an upper respiratory tract infection needs to be taken for emergency foreign body removal from the esophagus. What would be the inhalational agent of choice in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for children, especially in emergencies, because of its sweet smell , smooth induction , and minimal airway irritation , making it ideal for patients with upper respiratory infections.
  • ➤ Sevoflurane
  • ➤ sweet smell
  • ➤ smooth induction
  • ➤ minimal airway irritation

questions.text: You are asked to take intravenous access for a 3-year-old child who is going to undergo tonsillectomy under general anesthesia. Identify the gauge of IV cannula commonly used in pediatrics.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 26G

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 3-year-old child , a 26G cannula is a commonly used size for IV access, ensuring minimal trauma and a more comfortable experience for the child.
  • ➤ 3-year-old child
  • ➤ 26G cannula

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding the difference between the adult and pediatric airway?

options.label: A
options.text: Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.

options.label: C
options.text: Epiglottis is at a higher level in children than adults.

options.label: D
options.text: Larynx is funnel shaped in children

questions.correct_answer: A. Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pediatric patients, the tongue-to-mouth ratio is larger compared to adults, making the airway relatively more difficult to manage. The epiglottis is floppy , the larynx is funnel-shaped , and the epiglottis is higher in children than in adults.
  • ➤ tongue-to-mouth ratio is larger
  • ➤ epiglottis is floppy
  • ➤ larynx is funnel-shaped
  • ➤ epiglottis is higher

questions.text: Calculate the maintenance fluid for the first hour of surgery in a child weighing 10 kg.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 40 ml/hr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child weighing 10 kg , the maintenance fluid for the first hour of surgery, according to the Holiday-Segar formula , is 40 ml/hr .
  • ➤ 10 kg
  • ➤ Holiday-Segar formula
  • ➤ 40 ml/hr

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown in the picture.

options.label: A
options.text: For intubation in an anticipated difficult airway

options.label: B
options.text: Guide placement of double lumen tube

options.label: C
options.text: Suction of blood from the airways

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fiberoptic bronchoscope is a critical tool in airway management, especially in difficult intubation scenarios, guiding double-lumen tube placement, and clearing blood or secretions from the airway.
  • ➤ fiberoptic bronchoscope

questions.text: For which of the following purposes is glycopyrrolate commonly used as a preanesthetic agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreasing secretions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to decrease secretions , which helps in maintaining a clear airway and reduces the risk of complications during anesthesia.
  • ➤ Glycopyrrolate
  • ➤ decrease secretions
